Posts.Title: BMX and the Media Debra46 NatsFan

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2013 11:28AM juliaanna wrote: cdavis, Special K was right about the Oncotyping of biopsy samples.  My biopsy only showed mucinous, so the Oncotyping would have only been on that.  It wasn't until we got the pathology from the lumpectomy that ILC, DCIS, IDC was discovered.  The Oncotyping was done on all three.  My MO actually wanted to wait until my BMX to send in "newer" samples, but testing was already started on the samples from the lumpectomy. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: May 31, 2013 08:21PM juliaanna wrote: Southernangel, I didn't have that happen to me.  I'm a nurse and it sounds like it might be an infection/cellulitis.  If it is, the antibiotics will help.  Does it feel warmer than the surrounding skin?  You might check with your doctor about using warm packs instead of ice-that might help more with the pain. Take care.
Posts.Title: just a shout out to everyone waiting over this long weekend - debmc1958 anastaisa99

Posts.Content: May 31, 2013 09:27PM juliaanna wrote: Cellulitis is an infection in the upper layers of the skin rather than deeper in the tissue.  Do take the antibiotics.  When the fluid accumulates, it is called a seroma.  I had one develop after my lumpectomy.  My BS drained it, which helped the discomfort.  Most of the time, over time, the body reabsorbs the fluid.  Do take it easy.  This is the time to pamper yourself a bit.
Posts.Title: just a shout out to everyone waiting over this long weekend - debmc1958 anastaisa99

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2013 12:55AM juliaanna wrote: Cactus, sorry your biopsy experience was so painful. I would go ahead and insist on an ultrasound. Masses aren't always palpable. Do what gives you peace of mind. This is all about you, not what the insurance directs or what the doctor thinks or "normal protocol". Best wishes, J
Posts.Title: Should I insist on ultrasound of the other breast? cactus cactus

Posts.Content: May 30, 2013 01:34AM juliaanna wrote: Doreen, You can stop the fill process anytime and you can insist on having the tissue expanders removed.  If your PS won't do it, find another doctor. No one should have to be in so much pain.  This is your body and your life.  You have the right to be comfortable and have a good quality of life in spite of fighting cancer.   It seems like your PS started your fills pretty quickly after surgery.  I was filled with 100 at surgery, but didn't start the fills until 4 weeks after surgery and then only 50 cc's at a time. You need to heal from the surgery first. Take care.  Stand your ground.   Keeping you in my thoughts and prayers.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy & Reconstruction jstans curveball

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2012 06:54PM juliaanna wrote: cmparker, Is it possible you were given IM injections in your thigh/buttocks?  Sometimes that cause numbness/shooting pains.  Or it could be from being in those "wonderfully comfortable" hospital bed.  Hope everything else is going smoothy with your recovery.  Remember to take it easyi-let others wait on you.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2013 12:45AM - edited Sep 8, 2013 12:46AM by juliaanna You might try taking Vitamin C (500 mg/ two -three times a day) and Zinc (220 mg/ two-three times a day).  Take them together.  We give this to our geriatric folks who have wounds that are slow to heal.  My MO also suggested it to me even though I was not having issues healing.  Be sure to check with your doctor first.   Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 04:52AM juliaanna wrote: Misshopeful, Welcome but sorry you have to be here.  I'm a nurse, too, so I know how our vocation colors our thinking.  Waiting is the worst part of this whole deal.  I had to delay my lumpectomy by 2 weeks because I caught a cold and then my BS was on vacation.  When I learned I had to have the BMX, I delayed surgery so (1) I could start reconstruction at the same time-surgeons had to coordinate schedules and (2) my first grandchild was due in late April.  I wanted time to enjoy her before surgery.  In my case, it was okay to wait a few months.  Hope everything goes well with you.  There is a nurses with breast cancer thread and a February 2013 surgery thread that you might wish to check out.  I'm here for you, too.  Just let me know how I can help you.  You will be in my thoughts and prayers.
Posts.Title: recently diagnosed misshopeful misshopeful

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 09:46PM juliaanna wrote: Vera, Do, indeed, let go of that RN imagination. Remember as nurses, we tend to recall the worst cases. There are plenty of "not quite so bad" outcomes. I hope you can get in soon for your biopsy. Do you take aspirin or any other blood thinners? Stop taking them/check with your MD. They usually want you off of them for 5 days before the biopsy. The last thing you want is to have any testing delayed because of the ASA or fish oil, etc. Once I found out I was in for a number of test, biopsy, lumpectomy, etc, I just stopped taking the 81mg of ASA the doc suggested I take. It worked to my advantage as some of the procedures were moved up due to cancellations.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2014 12:40AM - edited Mar 29, 2014 01:43AM by juliaanna NS, So sorry you find yourself here.  Rule #1-stay away from Dr. Google!  You will get good, timely information here.  On Monday, call and ask to be put on the cancellation list, then you will have a chance of getting in sooner.  Waiting is the very worst (so much for grammar) part of this experience.  Try to keep busy.  And it's okay to let the emotions go, especially here.  We'll give you unconditional support.  Weekends can be slow, but I know others will be along with good words for you. Take care. J
Posts.Title: Wishing I had more answers... NSwrites juliaanna

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2013 12:20AM juliaanna wrote: Sometimes neurontin/gabapentin can work on nerve pain. Have you had any fills? Sometimes the TEs are sitting on nerves and once they are inflated a bit, the pressure is relieved. If your PS won't give you meds to help, check with your Primary MD or your oncologists. Being in pain is not acceptable..and the docs don't always have any concept of what we experience. Best wishes

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2013 10:33PM - edited Jan 19, 2013 12:42AM by juliaanna Coraleliz, The flu vaccine is given to children under 4 in 2 shots, a few weeks apart.  It is a different formulation.  There is also a "double strength" formula for the "elderly" but there doesn't seem to be much difference in the effectiveness and Medicare won't pay for it. Call me crazy, but in 36 years of being a nurse, I have never heard of needing to use the deltoid only.  If I did that on some of my 85 pound/98 year old residents, I would have hit bone.  There are just a few drugs that require deep IM (gluteus) sites but that's the only site restriction I know about.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 05:55AM juliaanna wrote: Corgiluv22, I think you probably have the "bug".  I've been a nurse for many years and haven't heard of the radiation, in such a small dose, causing illness.  There may have been a "bug" where you had the mammogram.  Take care, drink plenty of fluids (couple sips at a time) and rest.  Hope you feel better soon.  Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2012 06:51AM juliaanna wrote: Mafe, Welcome, glad you found us, but sorry we have to meet like this.  There are many forums that you will find helpful.  I'd like to invite you to join the November 2012 surgeries group.  There are many of us there representing all stages of treatment, surgical and otherwise.   There are multiple tests and procedures in your future.  Lots of waiting which is the worst.  Then there will be tons of information and options thrown at you.  Start a file so you can keep copies of all your test results and other information you will accumulate.  Make sure you take time to process what is being told to you before you make any decisions.  Take someone with you to all your appointments so they can take notes for you or ask questions you might forget to ask.   I don't have much insight about dealing with cancer and being a mom of an almost 4 year old.  My daughters are 31 and 27.  I do know there will be many women here who will be coming forward to offer help with your concerns.  (Weekends are usually a bit slow here). Please remember you are not alone-come here any time you need a hug, need to vent, cry or celebrate (we still get to do that from time to time ).  Feel free to send me a PM anytime.
